awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Anatomy Reimagined in an Educational Tool with Gaming and 3D Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will lead to new educational software for learning human anatomy.  The software will serve 54,000 healthcare professional students studying anatomy each year in the U.S., as well as 450,000 undergraduate students.  Anatomy is the cornerstone of medical education with cadaver dissection serving as the gold standard teaching method. However, many students have limited or no access to cadavers during their academic experience.  Learning resources in human anatomy (textbooks, models, apps) are generally color-coded, computer-generated images that lack the complexities and appearance of cadavers. These learning materials do not match dissected specimens, making knowledge transfer more difficult.  To overcome these challenges, the proposed software will marry digital cadaveric models with captivating educational gaming strategies. The software will bring high-quality anatomy education to low resource settings in the U.S. and abroad.

The proposed project will incorporate principles of educational psychology and learning science to develop a gaming platform for healthcare professional students (e.g. medical, physical therapy, dental, physician assistant) to learn human anatomy. The games will be built on a virtual atlas of human anatomy created from high-resolution images of dissected human cadavers. For this proof-of-feasibility project, we will focus on the human heart. Technical hurdles to this project include incorporating learning principles into the games and converting anatomy images into a software package that can run on devices, such as iPads and smartphones, while maintaining resolution and usability features. During this project, we will capture images of the human heart, transfer them into the appropriate software development platform, and then add education features and games in an iterative process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Anatomy is the cornerstone of medical education, providing a framework of knowledge central to all medical careers. Anatomy courses and training are directed at multiple levels, from undergraduates and graduate/professional students who take an anatomy course each year to the thousands of established physicians and healthcare professionals who meet their continuing medical education requirements through workshops to learn new medical procedures.

Students most effectively master human anatomy when cadavers are available for hands on exploration, dissection, and practice of procedures. Cadavers, however, are also the primary pain point for anatomy education because of limited supply and cost.  The majority of students at all levels have limited or no access to cadavers or predissected specimens (prosections). The disruptions to in-person educational opportunities during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic have made access to cadavers even more challenging.

To augment hands-on learning with cadavers or prosections, students use a variety of resources including lectures and lecture notes, textbooks with 2D illustrations, plastic models, and digital apps using computerized illustrations.  The digital resources available to help individuals learn anatomy represent a leap forward from what was previously available in that three-dimensional (3D) visualizations can be achieved in a virtual environment. Quality of the visualizations, however, is still lacking.  Some 3D images in available apps have been compiled from two-dimensional (2D) idealized drawings that do not reflect the nuances and variation of real anatomic specimens.  Other apps have created 3D images from compiling and colorizing radiological images, which are sorely lacking in detail and resolution.

During Phase I, Dissect 360 built a novel anatomy learning app for the heart that is fully 3D, realistic, and exquisitely detailed. Dissect 360 leveraged gaming technologies to create a fun, motivating, and interactive virtual learning environment to promote anatomy learning and assessment. The core component of Dissect 360 is true 360-degree photography of real anatomic specimens.  For the first time ever, there is a learning resource available to use anywhere, anytime that replicates the color, complex 3D structure, and level of detail formerly visible only in the cadaver lab.  The Phase I prototype includes an interactive 3D atlas of three successive layers of the human heart, two digital based learning games, and an imaging game demonstration incorporating 2D clinical images with the 3D heart. All objectives from Phase I were met and are described below.

In Phase I the educational application of the heart atlas and games was developed as proposed. The ability of the application to meet the desires of health care professional students was demonstrated in our focus/usability testing groups.  The current heart application is educational, fun, engaging, and exquisitely detailed. Learners rated the app using the User Engagement Survey-Short Form and the System Usability Scale.  A high level of engagement was achieved in the single-site groups who completed the survey, suggesting strong engagement. The highest score, 4.75 out of 5.0, was in the reward domain which is the sole component of the User Engagement Survey-Short Form associated with long term engagement.  Ninety five percent of learner interactions with the application were observed to be highly social and collaborative. During gameplay, student interactions that occurred were high energy with laughter and cheering observed as well as spontaneous comments that the experience was fun. The mean System Usability Scale score was 86.22 ± 10.55.  The average SUS score for apps is 68 on a scale from 0-100, with 100 being the best. For an app scoring above 80, users will typically recommend the app to a friend. When we asked which aspect of the app was most helpful, 60.5% of learners found the games (Swipe Game and Find This) to be most helpful.

The prototype developed in Phase I has wide ranging applications and can be incorporated into a wide array of educational settings from high school anatomy classes, low resource medical schools without cadaver labs, training for healthcare providers who do not have time or money to attend a cadaver anatomy course. The Dissect 360 educational software provides a fully 3D, realistic, fun, and interactive resource of the human heart for anatomy learners; advantageous for both those with and without access to cadaveric specimens.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Sean P Maloney
